<para>Mark the words “TO STRUT” on the strut end marking location, indicated in <grphcref refid="f1-72-1480-0-1" shownow="0"> Figure 1 </grphcref>of this Service Bulletin. Refer to the SPM, 70-16-03, ELECTROCHEMICAL ETCH MARKING.</para> </l2item> </list2> </l1item> </list1> </pretopic> </tfmatr> <graphic chg="n" key="f1-72-1480-0" revdate="20140703"> <sheet chg="n" gnbr="g5012941-00" key="f1-72-1480-0-1" revdate="20140703" sheetnbr="1"> <title>D-Sump Oil Supply Tube and Marking Location</title> </sheet> <sheet chg="n" gnbr="g5012942-00" key="f1-72-1480-0-2" revdate="20140703" sheetnbr="2"> <title>D-Sump Oil Supply Tube and Marking Location</title> </sheet> </graphic> </task>

FUSELAGE - Skin - Inspection Of The SkinFor Scribe Lines GENERAL INFORMATION KEEP THE WORK AREA, WIRES AND ELECTRICAL BUNDLES CLEAN OF METAL PARTICLES OR CONTAMINATION WHEN YOU USE TOOLS. UNWANTED MATERIAL, METAL PARTICLES OR CONTAMINATION CAUGHT IN WIRE BUNDLES CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE BUNDLES. DAMAGED WIRE BUNDLES CAN CAUSE SPARKS OR OTHER ELECTRICAL DAMAGE. The instructions identified in Paragraph 3.B., Work Instructions and the Figure(s) give the recommended sequence of steps. The sequence of steps to do this service bulletin can be changed. Manual titles are referred to by acronyms. Refer to Paragraph 1.J., References, for definition of the acronyms. Obey all of the warnings and cautions given in the specified manual sections. Unless shown differently, these dimensions and tolerances are used: Linear dimensions are in inches Tolerance on linear dimensions, other than rivet and bolt edge margins, is plus or minus 0.03 inch. A Detailed Inspection is defined as: An intensive examination of a specific item, installation, or assembly to detect damage, failure, or irregularity. Available lighting is normally supplemented with a direct source of good lighting at an intensity deemed appropriate. Inspection aids such as mirrors magnifying lenses, etc. may be necessary. Surface cleaning and elaborate procedures may be required. A General Visual Inspection is defined as: A visual examination of an interior or exterior area, installation or assembly to detect obvious damage, failure or irregularity. This level of inspection is made from within touching distance unless otherwise specified. A mirror may be necessary to ensure visual access to all surfaces in the inspection area. This level of inspection is made under normal available lighting conditions such as daylight, hangar lighting, flashlight or drop-light and may require removal or opening of access panels or doors. Stands, ladders or platforms may be required to gain proximity to the area being checked. These work instructions refer to procedures included on other Boeing documents. When the words "refer to" are used and the operator has an accepted alternative procedure, the accepted alternative procedure can be used. When the words "in accordance with" are included in the instruction, the procedure in the Boeing document must be used. Refer to Appendix A for sealant removal procedures for exterior pressurized fuselage skin. Refer to Appendix B for reporting system for limited return to service procedure for scribe line airplanes. Refer to Appendix C for airplane fuselage scribe line mark summary tables. Refer to Appendix D for scribe line sample. Appendix D includes information for the fabrication or purchase of a scribe line sample for use as a training aid. The use of this sample is not required when performing actions of this service bulletin. This sample is an aid in identifying what a scribe line may look and feel like but is not intended to show all damage that is considered a scribe line. When identifying scribe lines see the definition of a typical scribe line in Part 7 of the accomplishment instructions. In the figures, lap joints and butt joints areas to be inspected are indicated with heavy lines. Decal and repair areas to be inspected are shaded. No repair or additional inspection is required for scribes found in fuselage skin areas not shown in this service bulletin provided they are typical as defined in Part 7, and 0.006 inch or less deep. Contact Boeing if scribe lines are found outside of areas noted in this service bulletin that are deeper than 0.006 inch for repair and inspection instructions. Refer to Part 7 for the definition of a typical scribe line. If an optical micrometer or laser measurement system cannot be used because the upper skin of the lap joint covers a scribe line, then the scribe line depth does not need to be determined at that location.These scribe lines must be considered typical and therefore all inspection and other requirements for a typical scribe line apply. It is required that individuals performing ultrasonic inspections on airplanes with scribe lines to detect cracks per the relevant procedures must be recognized by the operator or repair station as qualified to perform ultrasonic inspections on their airplanes and meet at least one of the following criteria: The individual must be qualified to at least Level II in the ultrasonic method in accordance with an accepted industry standard, i.e. ATA Specification105, Mil-Std.-410, NAS-410, SNT-TC-1A, or EN-4179 or equivalent. or The individual has received specific Boeing training with Boeing providing a certificate stating that the individual has satisfactorily completed thetraining in the specific techniques. or The individual has a level I in the ultrasonic method in accordance with an accepted industry standard and has received specific training and a statement from the qualifying entity (employer) that the individual is qualified for this particular inspection. If scribe lines are found during any of the inspections contained in this service bulletin, when determining the requirements for inspection and repair, each scribe line shall be considered individually. Approved repair is identified as any SRM repair, repair provided and approved by Boeing for specific cases that were requested by the operator, or operator developed repair that has Boeing approved Damage Tolerance Analysis. Contact Boeing if any scribe line is detected at a non Boeing approved repair. WORK INSTRUCTIONS PART 1 - SKIN LAP JOINT - ZONE 1 INSPECTION Do the skin lap joint - Zone 1 inspection as follows: Group 1: Prepare the skin lap joint for inspection as shown below and at the locations in accordance with Figure 1. Remove the sealant as required from the lower edge of all affected lap joints. Refer to Appendix A of this service bulletin as an accepted procedure for sealant removal. Remove the paint as required from below the lower edge of all affected lap joints. The bared area should be at least one inch wide, as measured from the lower edge of the upper skin. Do an external detailed inspection of the fuselage skin for any scribe line in accordance with Figure 1. The use of 10X magnifying lens is required for this inspection. Refer to Part 7 for identification of a typical scribe line. In areas near lap joints, scribe lines normally run parallel to the lap joint in the lower skin along the edge of the upper skin. These scribe lines are typically within 0.25 inches of the lower edge of the upper skin. In some cases, portions of the scribe lines may be directly adjacent to or slightly under the lower edge of the upper skin. The ends of these scribe lines sometimes may also turn slightly away from the lap joint. If any skin scribe line is found, do the Part 8 - Scribe Line Found. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair procedures and do the repair. If no scribe line is found, no further inspection is required at this location, provided that the correct sealant removal procedure is implemented for all future work. Refer to Appendix A of this service bulletin as an accepted sealant removal procedure. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. PART 5 - EXTERNAL APPROVED REPAIR - INSPECTION Do the external approved repair inspection at the time given in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance as follows: If applicable, do the external approved repair inspection as follows: Do one of the options that follow: In areas located between STA 360 and STA 1016 and below stringer 10 left and stringer 10 right. Determine if the external repair doubler is 20 inches or longer in the fore and aft direction with no circumferential limitations. Inspection is not required on external approved repairs located between STA 360 and STA 1016 and below stringer 10 left and stringer 10 right which are less than 20 inches long in the fore and aft direction. In areas where all or part of the external approved repair is located between STA 360 and STA 1016 and above stringer 10 left and stringer 10 right. Determine if the external repair doubler is 20 inches or longer in the fore and aft direction or wider than 12 inches circumferentially. Inspection is not required around external approved repairs located between STA 360 and STA 1016, above stringer 10 left and stringer 10 right which are less than 20 inches long in the fore and aft direction and smaller than 12 inches circumferentially. Determine the thickness of the parent skin in the area of the repair. Refer to the Boeing drawings if the skin thickness is not known. Refer to 737 SRM chapter 53 for the applicable Boeing drawings. At the operators option refer to 737 NDT, Part 4, 51-00-00 Figure 2 as an accepted procedure to determine the thickness of the parent skin. Remove paint and sealant from the area of the skin around the periphery of the external repair doubler. Refer to Appendix A of this service bulletin as an accepted procedure for sealant removal. The bared area should be at least one inch wide, around the periphery of the repair doubler. Do an external detailed inspection of the fuselage skin for scribe lines in the area of bare skin around the doubler in accordance with Figure 25. The use of 10X magnifying lens is required for this inspection. Refer to Part 7 for identification of a typical scribe line. Scribe lines normally follow the periphery of the doubler. If any skin scribe line is found, do the Part 8 - Scribe Line Found. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair procedures and do the repair. If no scribe line is found, no further inspection is required at this location, provided that the correct sealant removal procedure is implemented for all future work. Refer to Appendix A of this service bulletin as an accepted sealant removal procedure. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. Determine if the internal approved repair skin cut-out is greater than 20 inches long in the fore and aft direction with no circumferential limitations. Inspection is not required on internal approved repairs located between STA 360 and STA 1016 and below stringer 10 left and stringer 10 right which are less than 20 inches long in the fore and aft direction. PART 7 - IDENTIFICATION OF A "TYPICAL" SCRIBE LINE Determine if the scribe line is "typical": A scribe line is defined as a narrow, shallow, distinct line of damage (typically up to 0.006 inch deep), usually associated with the removal of a fillet or gap seal (lap joints and butt joints, respectively). Scribe lines can be both tactile and non-tactile. Discoloration of the aluminum clad layer or small surface imperfections do not qualify as a scribe line. A lightning strike at a lap joint or butt joint does not qualify as a scribe line. In certain cases the scribe lines have also been associated with the trimming of fuselage skin decals. Scribe lines that create a potential safety concern are generally long continuous scribe lines or several adjacent scribe lines in a critical orientation at specific locations with relatively high stresses. Figures are included in the Service Bulletin to depict typical scribe line found common to lap joints, butt joints, repairs, and decals. Grinding, gouging, or other "non-typical" damage, which is more significant (deeper or locally more extensive) than the typical scribe line must be repaired before further flight. Localized scratches, nicks and dents that might be induced in other areas of the fuselage skin during either manufacture or maintenance operations are not considered scribe lines. This type of damage should be addressed via the acceptable maintenance practices detailed in the Structural Repair Manual. PART 8 - SCRIBE LINE FOUND Document the location of all scribe line that was found. It is recommended that you use the format outlined in Appendix B to document the scribe line. Do an external detailed inspection of the scribe line to find the deepest scribe location on the airplane for the applicable Zone. At the deepest scribe location, do a laser measurement inspection or a optical micrometer inspection to measure the maximum depth of the scribe line. Only the laser measurement inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 10, 53-30-01 can be used to confirm scribe line depth less than 0.001 inch. If the scribe line depth is less than 0.001 inch, no further work or inspection is required at this location provided: No depth along this scribe line is greater than or equal to 0.001 inch. The correct sealant removal procedure is implemented for all future work. Refer to Appendix A of this service bulletin as an accepted sealant removal procedure. If the scribe line depth is greater than or equal to 0.001 inch and less than or equal to 0.006 inch do one of the options that follow: Do the Part 9 - Scribe Line Inspection. Contact Boeing for repair instructions and do the repair. If the scribe line depth is greater than 0.006 inch contact Boeing for repair procedures and do the repair. PART 9 - SCRIBE LINE INSPECTION Once the deepest scribe line location has been determined to be less than or equal to 0.006 inch and scribe line is crack free, then all other scribe line locations within the applicable lap joints qualify for the Limited Return To Service (LRTS) program repeat inspections. If the scribe line exists in an affected lap joint location: At all lap joints where scribe line depth is greater than or equal to 0.001 inches and less than or equal to 0.006 inches, do the inspections of the skin, as follows: If a scribe is detected within 0.10 inches of the edge of the lap splice, inspection has to be performed along the entire length of the lap splice, from forward butt joint to aft butt joint. If a scribe line is located in an area outside the 0.10 inch zone, then the inspection is only required locally common to the scribe. If applicable, remove the sealant from the lower edge of the entire lap joint from the butt joint forward of the scribe line to the butt joint aft of the scribe line. Refer to Appendix A of this service bulletin as an accepted procedure for sealant removal. If applicable, remove the paint from below the lower edge of the entire lap joint from the butt joint forward of the scribe line to the butt joint aft of the scribe line. The bared area should be at least one inch wide, as measured from the lower edge of the upper skin. Do the inspections of the fuselage skin to detect any crack at all affected lap joints in accordance with Figure 47. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. If no crack is found, do the Part 10 - LRTS program repeat inspection at the times shown in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance or contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. If a scribe line exists in a circumferential butt joint area: At all circumferential butt joints where scribe line depth is greater than or equal to 0.001 inches and less than or equal to 0.006 inches, do the inspection as follows: If a repair or modification is common to the circumferential butt joint and an external scribe line crack inspection is required contact Boeing for the proper inspection method. Do an external Low Frequency Eddy Current (LFEC) sliding probe inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-24 or an internal Medium Frequency Eddy Current (MFEC) inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-23 or an external High Frequency Eddy Current (HFEC) pencil probe inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-29 or a internal HFEC inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00 figure 23 to detect any crack. If internal MFEC or internal HFEC inspections are used, the areas of the splice plate covered by production stringers, shear ties, or production internal splice plates do not require eddy current inspections. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. If no crack is found, do the Part 10 - LRTS program repeat inspection at the times shown in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance or contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. If a scribe line exists around a decal: At all decal areas where scribe line depth is greater than or equal to 0.001 inches and less than or equal to 0.006 inches, do the inspection as follows: Do the inspections of the fuselage skin to detect any crack at all affected decals as follows: Do a HFEC inspection to detect any crack in scribe lines at all affected decals in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00 Figure 4 or Figure 23. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. If no crack is found, do the Part 10 - LRTS program repeat inspection at the times shown in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance or contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. If a scribe line exists around an external repair doubler: At all external approved repairs where scribe line depth is greater than or equal to 0.001 inch and less than or equal to 0.006 inch, do the inspection as follows: If a scribe is detected within 0.10 inches of the external repair doubler, inspection has to be performed around the entire external repair doubler periphery. If the scribe is located at an area outside the 0.10 inches zone, then the inspection is only required locally common to the scribe. Do the inspections at all affected external approved repairs in accordance with Figure 47. If any crack is found in the above inspections, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. If no crack is found in the above inspections, do the Part 10 - LRTS program repeat inspection at the times shown in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance or contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. If a scribe line exists on an internal repair doubler (around the repair filler): At all internal approved repairs where scribe line depth is greater than or equal to 0.001 inch and less than or equal to 0.006 inch, do the inspection as follows: Do an external Low Frequency Eddy Current (LFEC) sliding probe inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-24 or an internal Medium Frequency Eddy Current (MFEC) inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-23 or an external High Frequency Eddy Current (HFEC) pencil probe inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-29 or an internal HFEC inspection in accordance with 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00, Figure 23 to detect any crack. If any crack is found in the above inspections, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. If no crack is found in the above inspections, do the Part 10 - LRTS program repeat inspection at the times shown in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance or contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. PART 10 - LIMITED RETURN TO SERVICE (LRTS) PROGRAM Skin lap joint - Zone 17 - Repeat inspection: Do the Zone 17 inspection as follows: If the scribe line is within 0.10 inches of the upper skin lower edge, then repeat inspections are required along the lap joint from the skin butt joint forward of the scribe line to the skin butt joint aft of the scribe line or the edge of a cut out forward or aft of the scribe line to the skin butt joint forward or aft of the scribe line. If the scribe line is located in an area that is outside of the 0.10 inches zone, then repeat inspections are only required locally common to the scribe. E., Compliance as follows: It is not necessary to remove the primer from the circumferential butt joint splice plate. Group 1-3, 5-8, 10: Determine which circumferential butt joint areas require inspections. Refer to documentation gathered in Part 8 - scribe line found and Figure 16 and Figure 17 for locations. Do an external LFEC sliding probe inspection or an internal MFEC inspection or an external HFEC pencil probe inspection or an internal HFEC inspection to detect any crack in the scribe line at circumferential butt joint STA 360 in accordance with Figure 42. If internal MFEC or internal HFEC inspections are used, the areas of the splice plate covered by production stringers, shear ties, or production internal splice plates do not require eddy current inspections. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. Do the Part 11- Surface Finish Restoration. External approved repair - Repeat inspection: Refer to documentation gathered in Part 8 - scribe line found and Figure 45 for location. Repairs that end on different thickness skin pockets have different repeat inspection intervals. Refer to Paragraph 1. E., Compliance. Do the inspections at all affected external approved repair as follows: If a scribe is detected within 0.10 inches of the repair doubler, inspections to detect any crack per the LRTS have to be performed around the entire repair doubler periphery. Remove paint and sealant as required from the area of the skin around the periphery of the external repair doubler. Refer to Appendix A of this service bulletin as an accepted procedure. The bared area should be at least one inch wide, around the periphery of the repair doubler. Do an external detailed inspection, HFEC inspection and an UT inspection to detect any crack in accordance with Figure 47. If the scribe damage is within 0.063 inches from the edge of the repair doubler, as an alternative to the above UT inspection and HFEC inspections an UT phased array inspection can be used. UT phased array inspection does not require paint removal. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. If no crack is found, continue to do the LRTS program inspections at the intervals given in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance or contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. Internal approved repair - Repeat inspection: Do the internal repair doubler repeat inspection at the time given in Paragraph 1. E., Compliance as follows: Repairs that end on different thickness skin pockets have different repeat inspection intervals. Refer to Paragraph 1. E., Compliance. Do the inspections at all affected internal approved repair as follows: Scribe lines normally follow the periphery of the repair filler in the gap between the skin and the repair filler. Remove sealant as required from within the gap between the skin and the repair filler. Refer to Appendix A of this service bulletin as an accepted procedure. Do an external LFEC sliding probe inspection or an internal MFEC inspection or an external HFEC pencil probe inspection or an internal HFEC inspection to detect any crack in accordance with Figure 46. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. If no crack is found, continue to do the LRTS program inspections at the intervals given in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance or contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. PART 11 - SURFACE FINISH RESTORATION To reduce the possibility of future scribing, Boeing recommends that the fillet seal not be reapplied except in the gap at the butt joint. Re-finish the external surface finish as follows: Apply Type 2, Class A chemical conversion coating. Refer to SOPM 20-43-03 as an accepted procedure. Apply BMS 10-72 paint system (primer plus enamel), or BMS 10-79 Type II (primer) plus BMS 10-60 Type II (topcoat), or the operators normal decorative paint system. Refer to 737-600/700/800/900 AMM 51-21-00 as an accepted procedure. If applicable, re-finish the internal surface finish as follows: Apply Type 2, Class A chemical conversion coating. Refer to SOPM 20-43-03 as an accepted procedure. Apply BMS 10-11 Type 1 primer. Put the airplane back to a serviceable condition. PART 12 - I NSPECTION REQUIREMENTS FOR SCRIBES FOUND PRIOR TO THE INITIAL INSPECTION THRESHOLD For scribe damage at a lap joint that is within the parameters of a "typical" scribe as defined in Part 7, inspect the fuselage skin locally common to the scribe to detect any crack in accordance with Figure 47. For scribes found before the applicable threshold, inspections are required only locally in all areas. If any crack is found, contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair. If no crack is found, do the Part 9 - Scribe Line Inspection upon reaching the threshold given in Paragraph 1.E., Compliance or contact Boeing for repair instruction and do the repair Do the Part 11 - Surface Finish Restoration. FIGURE 1: FUSELAGE - SKIN LAP JOINT - ZONE 1 INSPECTION This Figure applies to Group 1: The step numbers shown below agree with the numbers shown in the circle symbols in the figure. STEP TASK NAME IDENTIFICATION MORE DATA 1 Inspect Lower Skin S-4R, STA 360 To STA 1016. (a)(b) 2 Inspect Lower Skin S-4L, STA 360 To STA 1016. (a)(b) (a) Do an external detailed inspection of the fuselage skin for any scribe line. Use a 10X magnifying lens to aid the inspection. (b) In areas near lap joints, scribe lines normally run parallel to the lap joint in the lower skin alongthe edge of the upper skin. These scribe lines are typically within 0.25 inch of the lower edge ofthe upper skin. In some cases, portions of the scribe lines may be directly adjacent to or slightlyunder the lower edge of the upper skin. The ends of these scribe lines sometimes may also turnslightly away from the lap joint.

In some cases, portions of the scribe lines may be directly adjacent to or slightlyunder the lower edge of the upper skin. The ends of these scribe lines sometimes may also turnslightly away from the lap joint.

REQUIRED INSPECTIONS FOR SCRIBES FOUND WITHIN ONE INCH OF A SKIN LAP JOINT AND EXTERNAL APPROVED REPAIRS In each of the areas defined above, all of the inspections described in the table are necessary if scribes are found. The illustration shown above is not to scale. The illustration above shows a typical lap joint. The same dimensions apply to the edges of repair doublers. Initial inspections must be done with the paint removed. Area 1 Area 2 Area 3 For scribe lines in Area 1, all of the following inspections must be done from butt joint to butt joint, unless otherwise noted. For scribe lines in Area 2, all of the following inspections must be done from butt joint to butt joint, unless otherwise noted. For scribe lines in Area 3, all of the following inspections must be done. Butt joint to butt joint inspections are not required. Detailed (a) and either Option1 or Option 2 below. Detailed (a) and either Option 1 or Option 2 below. Detailed (a) and HFEC below. Option 1:Ultrasound. Single elementultrasonic as given in 737 NDT, Part 4, 53-30-05 (b)(d) and Surface HFEC as given in 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-22 (a) Option 1:Ultrasound. Single element ultrasonic asgiven in 737 NDT, Part 4, 53-30-05 (b)(d) and one of the following: Surface HFEC (c) as given in 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00 Figure 4 (a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00 Figure 23 (a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-26 (rotary probe)(a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-27 (spot probe) (a). Surface HFEC (c) as given in: 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00 Figure 4 (a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00Figure 23 (a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-26 (rotary probe) (a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-27 (spot probe) (a). Option 2:Ultrasound. Phased arrayultrasonic as given in 737 NDT, Part 4, 53-30-06 (a)(d) Option 2:Ultrasound. Phased array ultrasonic asgiven in 737 NDT, Part 4, 53-30-06 (a)(d) and one of the following: Surface HFEC (c) as given in 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00 Figure 4 (a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 51-00-00 Figure 23 (a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-26 (rotary probe)(a), or 737 NDT, Part 6, 53-30-27 (spot probe) (a). (a) After the initial inspection with the paint removed, subsequent inspections using this method can be accomplished with the paint in place. (b) The paint must be removed for this inspection. (c) This inspection is only required in the scribed area. (d) The skin thickness must be known when conducting the UT inspection. Refer to 737 SRM chapter 53 for the applicable Boeing drawings. At the operators option refer to 737 NDT, Part 4, 51-00-00 Figure 2 as an accepted procedure to determine the skin thickness.

A: SEALANT REMOVAL PROCEDURE FOR EXTERIOR PRESSURIZED FUSELAGE
SKIN" location="ad8621ca" manual="SERVICE BULLETIN" model="737" reference="TaskTAR545 APPENDIX A" revdate="20091118" revnum="1"/> <title>APPENDIX A: SEALANT REMOVAL PROCEDURE FOR EXTERIOR PRESSURIZED FUSELAGE SKIN</title> <tfmatr> <pretopic lbl="A."> <title>APPENDIX A: SEALANT REMOVAL PROCEDURE FOR EXTERIOR PRESSURIZED FUSELAGE SKIN</title> <list1> <l1item lbl="(1)"> <para>MATERIAL REQUIRED:</para> <list2> <l2item lbl="(a)"> <para>Scrapers.</para> <list3> <l3item lbl="1)"> <para>AC Tech Scraper, TS 1275-4 (6 inch length).</para> <para>Supplier: Advanced Chemistry & Technology (AC TECH) Address: 7341 Anaconda Avenue, Garden Grove, CA 92841, USA Phone: 714-373-2837 extension 119 or 117 Fax: 714-373-1913, Attn: Customer Service email: rosie.cruze@actechaero.com</para> <note> <para>Handles are also available for these products for better comfort and control. The handle best suited for the TS 1275-4 scraper can be purchased under the part number SHR 0272-T from AC Tech.</para> </note> </l3item> <l3item lbl="2)"> <para>SEMCO Scraper: P/N 234350 (6 inch length).</para> <para>Supplier: PPG Aerospace: SEMCO Division Address: PPG-Aerospace (ASC-Seattle), 14126 NE 190th Street, Woodinville, WA 98072, USA Phone: North America 800 237-6649 (This connects to the closest PPG Aerospace facility in North America. For North America and International contacts visit the web site.) China (Suzhou) 86 512 6661 5858 Dubai UAE 971 4 883 9666 France 33 0 5 6149 4849 Germany 49 40 742 193 10 Hong Kong 852 2861 0918 South Africa 27 11 608 5656 Singapore 65 861 1119 United Kingdom 44 0 1388 770222</para> <para>Web Site: www.ppg.com/prc-desoto/main.asp?img=asc email: Cheryl.Chittenden@PPG.com?subject=Semco Scrapers (PN-234350)</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="3)"> <para>Jus N Tyme Scrapers: P/N JNT 411B60 (6 inch length), P/N JNT 411B90 (9 inch length -tapered).</para> <para>Supplier: Jus N Tyme Tooling Address: 2167 Green Canyon Road, Fallbrook, CA 92028, USA Phone: 760 723-5985 Fax: 760 723-5820 Contacts: Cheryl or Bob Hancock Web Site: www.JusNTyme.com email: Bob@JusNTyme.com</para> <note> <para>Scraper P/N JNT 411B90 is designed for removing sealant from butt joints with a 1/4 inch or larger gap.</para> </note> </l3item> <l3item lbl="4)"> <para>PnJ Scrapers: P/N DFD5019, SCD5019, SFD7519, DAD5013 (5 and 9 inch lengths of varying widths); Plastic handles: P/N SHN0272, SHW0215, SHR0272.</para> <para>Supplier: PnJ Machining, Inc. Address: 2601 Inter Avenue, Puyallup, WA 98372, USA Phone: 253 841-0500 Fax: 253 840-1695 Contact: Paul Hogeboom Web site: www.pnjmachining.com</para> <note> <para>Scraper P/N DAD5013 is designed for removing sealant from butt joints with a 1/8 inch or larger gap.</para> </note> </l3item> <l3item lbl="5)"> <para>Elixair Scrapers: P/N 311/03/04, 311/06/06, 311/12/04, 311/12/06, 311/24/04, 311/24/06, 311/ 38/04, and 311/38/06 (7.5 inch length with handle of varying widths); Skyholder Rubber Handle: P/N 310/1; Skymill Pneumatic Scraper Sharpener: P/N 309/3; Skybag for sharpener: P/N 309/ 3B.</para> <para>Supplier: Elixair International Limited Address: Roman Hill Business Park, Broadmayne, Dorset DT2 8LY, United Kingdom Phone: 44 0 1305 853019 (within the UK); 44 1305 853019 (within the USA) Fax: 44 0 1305 852060 (within the UK); 44 1305 852060 (within the USA) Contact: Len McLaughlin Web site: www.elixair.co.uk email: sales@elixair.com or lenmclaughlin@elixair.co.uk</para> <note> <numlist numtype="nnp"> <numlitem> <para>Scraper P/N 311/03/06 is designed for removing sealant from butt joints with a 3 mm or larger gap.</para> </numlitem> <numlitem> <para>The pneumatic sharpener can be used to sharpen most plastic scrapers.</para> </numlitem> </numlist> </note> </l3item> <l3item lbl="6)"> <para>Custom Components LTD Scraper: P/N 10810 (6 inch length).</para> <para>Supplier: Custom Components LTD Address: Unit 3, Feltrim Business Park, Swords Co., Dublin Ireland Phone: 353 1 8901909 Fax: 353 1 8901907</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="7)"> <para>Bomatic, Inc. Scraper: P/N 1-6390-A (9 inch length - tapered).</para> <para>Supplier: Bomatic, Inc. Address: 1841 E. Acacia St., Ontario, CA 91761, USA Phone: 909 947 3900 Fax: 909 947 5969 Contact: Kjeld Hestehave, Cathy Macri Web site: www.bomatic.com</para> <note> <para>Scraper P/N 1-6390-A is designed for removing sealant from butt joints with a 1/4 inch or larger gap.</para> </note> </l3item> <l3item lbl="8)"> <para>General Tool & Supply Scraper: P/N ST982L-9ACE (9 inch length).</para> <para>Supplier: General Tool & Supply Address: 355 Trek Drive, Tukwila, WA 98188, USA Phone: 206 762-1500 Toll: 1 800-321-3305 Fax: 206 767-7026 Contact: Dean Zetty Web site: www.generaltool.com email: dzetty@generaltool.com</para> </l3item> </list3> </l2item> <l2item lbl="(b)"> <para>Power Tools</para> <list3> <l3item lbl="1)"> <para>3M SR cutter - No. 3, 0.40 inch diameter, P/N 48011-30096-2.</para> <note> <para>Any power tool that will accept the 3M SR Cutter and has a maximum speed of 850 RPM (at the cutter) can be used.</para> </note> </l3item> </list3> </l2item> <l2item lbl="(c)"> <para>Solvents</para> <list3> <l3item lbl="1)"> <para>Methyl Ethyl Ketone (MEK), ASTM D740.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="2)"> <para>Methyl Propyl Ketone (MPK), BMS 11-9, Grades 1 and 2.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="3)"> <para>Aliphatic Naptha, TT-N-95, Type I and Type III.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="4)"> <para>Toulene, TT-T-548 or ASTM D362.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="5)"> <para>Isopropyl Alcohol TT-I-736.</para> </l3item> </list3> </l2item> <l2item lbl="(d)"> <para>Miscellaneous</para> <list3> <l3item lbl="1)"> <para>Aluminum Oxide abrasive paper, 400 grit or finer.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="2)"> <para>Paper or wipers that meet the requirements of BSM 15-5.</para> </l3item> </list3> </l2item> </list2> </l1item> <l1item lbl="(2)"> <para>SEALANT REMOVAL NOTES:</para> <para>This appendix provides procedures for removing sealant from the exterior pressurized fuselage. Using these procedures will minimize the risk of damaging clad aluminum surfaces during sealant removal. The main areas of concern are:</para> <list2> <l2item lbl="(a)"> <para>Lap joints.</para> </l2item> <l2item lbl="(b)"> <para>Butt joints (including underlying splice plates).</para> </l2item> <l2item lbl="(c)"> <para>Other areas where sealant is present (i.e. wing to body fairings, windows, access doors, etc.).</para> </l2item> </list2> <para>Boeing recommends only approved scrapers and tools listed in Paragraph 1 of this appendix be used for removing sealant from the exterior fuselage. Alternately, it is acceptable to use other scrapers provided the meet the requirements of BSS7384 (Method for Evaluating Tool Materials for use on Unpainted Clad Aluminum). Commonly used scraper materials such as Lexan polycarbonate, acrylic (Plexiglas), Micarta fiber reinforced phenolic resins, metal, wood, and other hard plastics have been tested and found to scratch clad aluminum.</para> </l1item> <l1item lbl="(3)"> <para>SEALANT REMOVAL PROCESS: LAP JOINT FILLET</para> <list2> <l2item lbl="(a)"> <para>To remove the lap joint fillet, follow this procedure:</para> <list3> <l3item lbl="1)"> <caution> <para>PLEASE NOTE THAT THERE IS A POTENTIAL FOR THE SR CUTTER TO "RUN AWAY" AND CAUSE DAMAGE AT THE LAP JOINT AND SURROUNDING AREA. ALSO, IF THE CUTTER CONTACTS BARE METAL BENEATH THE SEALANT, THE CLAD ALUMINUM SKIN COULD BE DAMAGED. BEFORE USING THE 3M SR CUTTER, OPERATORS SHOULD BE TRAINED ON PROPER USAGE OF THIS TOOL AND SHOULD PRACTICE ON TEST PANELS OR PIECES TO PERFECT THEIR SKILLS IN WORKING WITH THE TOOL.</para> </caution> <para>Remove the majority of the fillet seal at the lap joint using any of the approved scrapers listed in Paragraph 1.A. of this appendix.</para> <para>As an alternative, the 0.4 inch diameter 3M SR Cutter listed in Paragraph 1.B. of this appendix can be used. To prevent the cutter from damaging the clad aluminum surface, do not remove the sealant to bare metal. There should be a thin layer of sealant remaining on the surface after removing the majority of the sealant with the 3M SR Cutter.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="2)"> <para>After removing the majority of the sealant with approved scrapers or the 3M SR Cutter, remove the remaining sealant with any of the solvents listed in Paragraph 1.C. of this appendix. An approved scraper (Paragraph 1.A.) or wiper (Paragraph 1.D.) can be used along with the solvent to help with the removal.</para> </l3item> </list3> </l2item> </list2> </l1item> <l1item lbl="(4)"> <para>SEALANT REMOVAL: BUTT JOINTS AND OTHER AREAS WHERE SEALANT IS PRESENT ON THE EXTERIOR FUSELAGE</para> <list2> <l2item lbl="(a)"> <para>To remove sealant in butt joints and other areas on the exterior fuselage, follow this procedure:</para> <list3> <l3item lbl="1)"> <caution> <para>THE 3M SR CUTTER IS RECOMMENDED FOR REMOVING SEALANT FROM LAP JOINTS, BUT NOT FROM BUTT JOINTS OR OTHER AREAS.</para> </caution> <para>Remove the bulk of the sealant using any of the approved scrapers in Paragraph 1.A. of this appendix. Scrapers designed specifically for removing sealant from butt joints are available (i.e. PnJ, Elixair, Bomatic, Jus N Tyme). The shape of an approved scraper can be modified to fit a butt joint or other areas, as required. One possible modification is shown below.</para> <graphic chg="r" key="ad862245" revdate="20091118"> <title>TaskTAR545 APPENDIX A FIGURE 1</title> <sheet chg="r" gnbr="1548889" key="ad862246" revdate="20091118" sheetnbr="1"/> </graphic> </l3item> <l3item lbl="2)"> <para>After removing the majority of the sealant with approved scrapers or the 3M SR Cutter, remove the remaining sealant with any of the solvents listed in Paragraph 1.C. of this appendix. An approved scraper (Paragraph 1.A.) or wiper (Paragraph 1.D.) can be used along with the solvent to help with the removal.</para> </l3item> </list3> </l2item> </list2> </l1item> <l1item lbl="(5)"> <para>SCRAPER MAINTENANCE</para> <list2> <l2item lbl="(a)"> <para>Scrapers dulled from use can be sharpened with 400 grit or finer aluminum oxide paper. Before using a sharpened scraper, the scraper should be rubbed on paper or cheesecloth (Paragraph 1.D.2.) to remove loose sanding particles. If an alternate method of sharpening is used, such as a metal sharpening wheel (including the Elixair Internation Limited pneumatic sharpener), rub the scraper on 400 grit or finer aluminum oxide paper after sharpening to remove debris, and then rub the scraper on paper or cheesecloth to remove loose particles.</para> </l2item> </list2> </l1item> <l1item lbl="(6)"> <para>USE OF CHEMICAL STRIPPERS TO ASSIST IN SEALANT REMOVAL FOR SCRIBE LINE INSPECTION</para> <list2> <l2item lbl="(a)"> <para>MATERIALS</para> <list3> <l3item lbl="1)"> <para>Cee-Bee E-1058, McGean-Rohco, Inc. Atlanta GA.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="2)"> <para>Eldorado PR-5044, Eldorado Chemical Company, Inc. San Antonio TX.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="3)"> <para>Elixair - Skyrestore (Thick), Elixair International Limited, Dorchester, England.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="4)"> <para>Naftosolv FN, Chemetall GMBH, Frankfurt, Germany.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="5)"> <para>Skycleen 2000 Aviation Cleaner, Solutia Inc. St. Louis, MO.</para> </l3item> <l3item lbl="6)"> <para>Turco 5351, Henkel Corporation, Madison Heights, MI.</para> </l3item> </list3> </l2item> <l2item lbl="(b)"> <para>SEALANT REMOVAL</para> <para>Use one of the following methods to remove sealant along lap and butt joints on the exterior fuselage.</para> <list3> <l3item lbl="1)"> <para>Method 1 - Mechanical/Chemical</para> <para>Remove sealant fillet with an approved scraper in accordance with Paragraph 1.A., above. Chemically strip any sealant remaining on the surface as follows:</para> <list4> <l4item lbl="a)"> <para>Mask surrounding areas as necessary to prevent contact with chemical strippers. Do not allow chemical strippers to contact substrates other than aluminum. Do not use chemical strippers on reverse lap joints.</para> <note> <para>Chemical strippers will soften and remove paint.</para> </note> </l4item> <l4item lbl="b)"> <para>Using a natural bristle brush, apply a thin coating of chemical stripper on the sealant.</para> <list5> <l5item lbl="<A>"> <caution> <para>CHEMICAL STRIPPER MAY PENETRATE INTO JOINTS IF GAPS ARE PRESENT DUE TO MISSING FAYING SURFACE SEALANT.</para> </caution> <para>Do not apply excessive chemical stripper. Stripper should hang and not flow.</para> </l5item> <l5item lbl="<B>"> <para>Let the stripper dwell until the sealant can be easily removed by dry wiping, but do not exceed 40 minutes dwell time.</para> </l5item> <l5item lbl="<C>">
<para>Remove softened sealant with clean dry wipers (BMS 15-5 Class A). Approved scrapers may be used in accordance with <refext refloc="51-31-00" refman="AMM" refmodel="737-600/700/800/900"> 737-600/700/800/900 AMM 51-31-00 </refext>to facilitate removal.</para> </l5item> </list5> </l4item> <l4item lbl="c)"> <para>After chemical stripping is complete, remove stripper by thoroughly washing with a waterbased alkaline cleaner approved for painted surfaces in accordance with SOPM 20-30-03. Rinse off alkaline cleaner with water.</para> </l4item> </list4> </l3item> <l3item lbl="2)"> <para>Method 2 - Chemical/Mechanical/Chemical</para> <list4> <l4item lbl="a)"> <para>Mask surrounding areas as necessary to prevent contact with chemical strippers. Do not allow chemical strippers to contact substrates other than aluminum.</para> <para/> </l4item> <l4item lbl="b)"> <para>Using a natural bristle brush, apply a thin coating of chemical stripper on the sealant fillet.</para> </l4item> <l4item lbl="c)"> <para>Let the chemical stripper dwell for a maximum of 4 hours, except use a maximum dwell time of 2 hours if Turco 5351 is used. A thin coat of stripper may be brushed on every hour as necessary to maintain a wet surface. Do not apply excessive stripper. Stripper should hang and not flow.</para> </l4item> <l4item lbl="d)"> <para>Do not apply chemical stripper to areas where the joint is exposed.</para> </l4item> <l4item lbl="e)">
<para>Remove softened sealant with an approved scraper in accordance with <refext refloc="51-31-00" refman="AMM" refmodel="737-600/700/800/900"> 737-600/700/800/900 AMM 51-31-00 </refext> and clean dry wipers (BMS 15-5 Class A).</para> </l4item> <l4item lbl="f)"> <para>Repeat steps b., c., d., and e. if necessary, but do not apply chemical stripper to areas where the joint is exposed.</para> </l4item> <l4item lbl="g)"> <para>If any sealant remains on the surface after removing the sealant fillet, follow the procedure outlined in Method 1.</para> </l4item> <l4item lbl="h)">
<para>After chemical stripping is complete, remove stripper by thoroughly washing with a waterbased alkaline cleaner approved for painted surfaces in accordance with <refext docnbr="20-30-03" refman="SOPM" refspl="BOEING: 81205"> SOPM 20-30-03</refext>. Rinse off alkaline cleaner with water.</para> </l4item> </list4> </l3item> </list3> </l2item> </list2> </l1item> </list1> </pretopic> </tfmatr> </task>

APPENDIX C: AIRPLANE FUSELAGE SCRIBE LINE MARK SUMMARY TABLES APPENDIX C: AIRPLANE FUSELAGE SCRIBE LINE MARK SUMMARY TABLES TaskTAR545 APPENDIX C FIGURE 1 Location Length (inches) Distance From Lap (Inches) Depth (inches) Stringer Forward Body Station Aft Body Station L d_fwd (a) d_min (b) d_aft (c) (a) d_fwd = Distance from the edge of the upper skin of the forward end of the scribe line. (b) d_min = Minimum distance of the scribe line at any point along the entire length of the scribe line from the edge of the upper skin. (c) d_aft = Distance from the edge of the upper skin of the aft end of the scribe line.
TaskTAR545 APPENDIX C FIGURE 2 Body Station Length (inches) Distance From Stringer (Inches) Depth (inches) L Upper Stringer d-x (a) Lower Stringer d-y (b) (a) d_x = Distance of the scribe upper end from the upper stringer. (b) d_y = Distance of the scribe lower end from the lower stringer. S- S- S- S- S- S- S- S-
TaskTAR545 APPENDIX C FIGURE 3 Forward Body Station Aft Body Station Stringer Length (inches) Distance From Stringer(Inches) Depth (inches) L d_fwd (a) d_aft (b) (a) d_fwd = Distance of the forward end of the scribe from the stringer. (b) d_aft = Distance of the aft end of the scribe from the stringer. s- s- s- s-

APPENDIX D: SCRIBE LINE SAMPLE APPENDIX D: SCRIBE LINE SAMPLE The instructions that follow can be used to make representative samples of the kinds of scribe line marks that may be found during the inspections specified in this service bulletin. This design is a visual inspection aid that can be used to familiarize visual inspectors with scribe lines and assure consistency between visual inspectors. The flag note 1 scribe line is intended to show the inspector how a scribe line can be hidden under a lap chamfer, requiring the inspector to look at an oblique angle to the lap joint edge to detect some scribes lines. The flag note 2 scribe line is intended to demonstrate a typical tactile scribe line. The flag note 3 scribe line is intended to demonstrate a shallow non-tactile scribe line. Minimum surface roughness is 125 micro inches. Unless otherwise noted, the following dimensions and tolerances are used: All dimensions are in inches. Tolerance on linear dimensions, other than rivet or bolt edge margins, is plus or minus 0.03inch. Tolerance on rivet or bolt edge margin is plus or minus 0.05 inch. Angular tolerance is plus of minus 2 degrees. Hole dimensions for standard solid rivets are given in 737 Structural Repair Manual, Chapter51. Make part A from bare 2024-T3 aluminum, 0.040 inch thick. 0.060 inch thick bare 2024-T3 is an acceptable substitute. Make part B from bare 2024-T3 aluminum, 0.071 inch thick. Fasten part B to part A with five 5/32 inch diameter countersunk rivets. Make the countersinks in part B. Make three typical scribe line marks on part A as follows: Flag Note 1: Scribe line part A with the tip of a razor knife, using one to two pounds down load with finger pressure on the knife handle. Displaced material from the scribing operation should remain on part A. Make sure that the scribe line is under the 20 degree chamfer on the edge of part B. Make sure the scribe line can be seen visually. Flag Note 2: Scribe line part A with the tip of a razor knife, using one to two pounds down load with finger pressure on the knife handle. Displaced material from the scribing operation should remain on part A. Make sure the scribe line is tactile (a fingernail can catch on the scribe line). Flag Note 3: Scribe line part A with one pass from the tip of a ball point pen, using 0.25 to 0.5 pound down load. Make sure the scribe line is not tactile (a fingernail does not catch on the scribe line). As an alternative to a ball point pen, use the edge of a 0.040 inch wide CRES plate, with 0.25 inch diameter radii at the corners of the plate.
